questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient having a ↓ MCV, ↓ MCH, ↓ transferrin saturation, ↓ serum ferritin, and ↑ Total iron binding capacity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron deficiency anemia

 

The lab findings indicate a microcytic hypochromic anemia, as shown by decreased Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV) and Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH).

 

The iron profile further confirms iron deficiency anemia: low transferrin saturation, low serum ferritin (indicating depleted iron stores), and increased Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC), which reflects the body’s attempt to bind more iron due to deficiency.

 

These findings are classic for iron deficiency anemia, where the primary pathology is a lack of iron needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalassemia: Thalassemia also presents as microcytic hypochromic anemia, but typically shows normal or increased serum ferritin and normal TIBC due to intact iron stores. The pattern of iron studies here does not fit thalassemia.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: This condition often shows low serum iron, but it is characterized by normal or increased ferritin and decreased TIBC, opposite to the findings in this question.

 

Option D. Sideroblastic anemia: Sideroblastic anemia is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis and abnormal iron incorporation into hemoglobin, leading to ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow. Serum iron is usually increased, and TIBC is normal or decreased, which does not match the iron deficiency profile described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is identified by microcytic hypochromic anemia with low serum ferritin, low transferrin saturation, and high TIBC, reflecting the body’s response to insufficient iron availability for hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

questions.text: A patient with chronic diarrhea develops dermatitis herpetiformis. The physician altered his diet which improved his symptoms. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. The immune system mistakenly targets gluten, along with the lining of the small intestine, leading to symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, and weight loss. One of the hallmark dermatological manifestations of celiac disease is dermatitis herpetiformis. This condition presents as a chronic, intensely itchy rash, typically on the elbows, knees, back, and buttocks, and is caused by the deposition of IgA antibodies at the dermoepidermal junction.

 

The improvement of symptoms following the alteration of the patient’s diet to exclude gluten is a classic indicator of celiac disease. Once gluten is removed from the diet, the intestinal inflammation subsides, and symptoms, including dermatitis herpetiformis, typically improve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whipple disease: Whipple disease is a rare bacterial infection that can cause malabsorption, leading to symptoms such as diarrhea and weight loss. However, it does not typically cause dermatitis herpetiformis, nor does dietary modification alone usually lead to symptom improvement.

 

Option C. Crohn disease: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that can cause chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. However, it does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and dietary changes like removing gluten do not usually lead to the dramatic improvement seen in celiac disease.

 

Option D. Lactose intolerance: Lactose intolerance results from the inability to digest lactose, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, diarrhea, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy products. It does not cause dermatitis herpetiformis, and the improvement in symptoms would be related to avoiding dairy, not gluten.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be suspected in patients presenting with chronic diarrhea and dermatitis herpetiformis, particularly when symptoms improve following a gluten-free diet.

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic drug. It also produces sedation and adverse effects like dry mouth and hypotension. All these actions result due to action on which of the following receptors?(INICET MAY 2024)

 

1. D2 and 5HT2 receptors

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic receptors

3. Muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic receptors

4. H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 3 and 4 are correct

 

Chlorpromazine is a typical anti-psychotic drug having main mechanism of antipsychotic action as D2 blockade and minor as 5 HT2 blockade. However, it also blocks many other receptors that can result in adverse effects.

 

While chlorpromazine does block H1 receptors causing sedation, it is not the sole receptor responsible for its adverse effects. It must be considered in conjunction with D2, 5HT2, muscarinic, and alpha-adrenergic receptors.

 

Other Option:

 

2. GABA and Beta-adrenergic Receptors: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors, hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of anti-psychotic drugs

 

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/470-471

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LES is open and UES is closed.
  2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
  3. Inspiration against a closed glottis.
  4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
  5. LES opens and UES opens.
  6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
     

LES: Lower esophageal sphincter

 

UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

 

The correct sequence of events during vomiting is:

 

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine: This begins the vomiting process, moving contents from the ileum towards the stomach.

 

4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter: This allows the contents to move from the small intestine into the stomach.

 

2. Strong contractions in the stomach: These contractions help to force the stomach contents upwards.

 

3. Inspiration against a closed glottis: This involves taking a deep breath with the glottis closed, increasing intra-abdominal pressure.

 

1. LES is open and UES is closed: Initially, the LES opens to allow the contents to move into the esophagus, while the UES remains closed.

 

5. LES opens and UES opens: Finally, both sphincters open to allow the contents to be expelled through the mouth.

 

Act of vomiting involves series of movements that takes place in GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sequence of events in act of vomiting:

 

  1. Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  2. Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  3. Closure of glottis
  4. Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  5. Elevation of soft palate
  6. Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  7. Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  8. Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  9. Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

 

The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i). Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii). Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphemia or pseudo hypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii). Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv). Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes.
  • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:
  • V – Vincristine
  • E – Etoposide
  • C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: A malignant brain tumor located in the posterior fossa, not associated with intraocular findings or leukocoria.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma affecting muscles, often presenting as a mass in the orbit but not causing leukocoria or associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option D. Astrocytoma: A tumor of the central nervous system (glial origin), which does not occur intraocularly and is not linked with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.

 

Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
 

1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE

  • This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.

 

2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.

 

3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

choices.text: Follow up with beta-hCG
Suction and evacuation

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

 

Explanation:

 

The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.

 

Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

 

Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 614

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

 

The Hemagglutination Test does not involve antibody marking. This test is used primarily to detect the agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) by substances such as viruses or anti-blood group antibodies. The principle behind hemagglutination involves the ability of certain entities like viruses to bind directly to receptors on the surfaces of RBCs, causing them to clump together without the need for an antibody to be present as a marker.

 

It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses antibodies that are tagged with an enzyme to detect the presence of antigens or other antibodies in a sample through a colorimetric change.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay: Involves antibodies or antigens labeled with a radioactive isotope to measure the concentration of substances in the blood.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Utilizes antibodies labeled with fluorescent dyes to detect specific antigens in tissues or cells under a fluorescence microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible
Clear eyes with a sterile swab
Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Bath to newborn with warm water

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended as it can cause rapid heat loss and hypothermia in the infant. Instead, after delivery, the newborn should be wiped clean with a sterile cloth and wrapped warmly without giving a bath. The bath can be delayed until at least 24 hours after birth or later when the baby’s body temperature has stabilized, especially in settings without advanced care facilities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start breastfeeding as soon as possible: It is recommended to initiate breastfeeding immediately after birth, ideally within the first hour for vaginal deliveries and within 4 hours for cesarean sections. Early breastfeeding provides the newborn with essential nutrients and antibodies and helps stimulate milk production.

 

Option B. Clear eyes with a sterile swab: Clearing the eyes of a newborn with a sterile swab is correct. If needed, antiseptic solutions like 1% silver nitrate or 1% tetracycline ointment can be used to prevent ophthalmia neonatorum, an eye infection that can occur in newborns.

 

Option D. Cover baby’s head and body: Covering the baby’s head and body immediately after birth is essential to prevent heat loss. Newborns lose up to 75% of their body heat through the head, making it crucial to keep the baby warm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman experiences a 2-year history of infertility, as well as experiencing dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and is sensitive in the Douglas pouch. What should be the subsequent course of action in her management? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TVS

 

In this case, the initial step in the diagnostic evaluation of suspected endometriosis is transvaginal ultrasound (TVS). TVS is the first-line imaging modality used to assess pelvic structures and identify abnormalities such as endometriomas or nodularity in the pouch of Douglas. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis and allows for direct visualization and biopsy, it is generally reserved for cases where non-invasive methods are inconclusive or when surgical intervention is planned. TVS provides valuable initial information and helps in guiding further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy is the definitive diagnostic procedure for endometriosis, it is not typically the first step. TVS is preferred initially to assess the presence of endometriosis-related changes and determine if more invasive procedures are necessary.

 

Option B. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is a more invasive surgical approach generally reserved for cases requiring larger abdominal incisions or when laparoscopy is not feasible. It is not typically used as an initial diagnostic tool for endometriosis.

 

Option C. HSG (Hysterosalpingography): HSG is used primarily to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes and uterine cavity. While it can assess tubal factor infertility, it does not provide information specific to endometriosis or the pelvic structures affected by it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of suspected endometriosis is to perform transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) to evaluate pelvic structures and identify abnormalities.

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence among those who were exposed compared to those who were not exposed? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Relative risk 

 

The ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).

 

 

Interpretation of RR

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attributable risk (AR):  is the difference in the risk of disease between the exposed and non-exposed groups, and represents the proportion of disease that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

Option B. Odds ratio (OR):  is the ratio of the odds of disease in the exposed group to the odds of disease in the non-exposed group.

 

Option D. Population attributable risk (PAR):  is the proportion of disease cases in the population that can be reduced if risk factor is modified or eliminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Relative Risk (RISK RATIO) is used to estimate risk of disease (calculated as incidence of that disease) with exposure to a factor
  • Relative risk (RR) IS A BETTER ESTIMATE of strength of association than Attributable risk (AR)
  • Strength of association:
    • Relative risk (cohort study)
    • Odds ratio (case control study)

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. Brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lewy bodies

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described (resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability) are characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

In Parkinson's disease, the brain biopsy is likely to show Lewy bodies. Lewy bodies are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of aggregates of alpha-synuclein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hirano bodies: Seen in Alzheimer's disease and other conditions like Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

 

Option C. Guarnieri bodies: (Type B inclusion) Found in cells infected with poxvirus.

 

Option D. Negri bodies: Seen in the neurons of patients with rabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Parkinson's disease, brain biopsies typically reveal Lewy bodies, which are intraneuronal, intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies made of alpha-synuclein.

questions.text: A person died suddenly whose family is abroad. A preservative was used to preserve his viscera. Which of the following poisoning is seen in it? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aconite

 

The question describes a scenario of sudden death where a preservative was used to preserve the viscera. The key point here is the suspicion of poisoning leading to sudden death. Aconite is a well-known cardiac poison that can cause sudden death by affecting the heart's function. Cardiac poisons such as aconite disrupt normal cardiac activity, leading to fatal arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol poisoning can be fatal, it typically does not cause sudden death in the manner described. The symptoms and progression of alcohol poisoning differ significantly from those of cardiac poisons.

 

Option B. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning usually presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and systemic toxicity. It is less likely to cause sudden cardiac death compared to aconite.

 

Option D. Thymol: Thymol is an antiseptic and fungicide, not typically associated with poisoning that leads to sudden death. Its toxic effects do not align with the scenario described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite is a potent cardiac poison known for causing sudden death due to its severe impact on cardiac function

 

Cardiac poisons: Mnemonic - DHONAQ

 

Digitalis, Hydrogen cyanide, Oleander, Nicotine, Aconite, and Quinine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to given drug? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malpresentation of fetus

 

Explanation:

 

The given drug in the image is Oxytocin, which is commonly used to induce or augment labor. However, its use is contraindicated in several conditions to avoid complications during childbirth. One such contraindication is malpresentation of the fetus, where the fetus is not in a head-down position, potentially complicating a vaginal delivery.

 

Contraindications to Oxytocin:

 

  • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times.
  • Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus.
  • History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture.
  • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus.
  • Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction.
  • Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns.
  • Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart disease in mother: Heart disease in the mother is considered a relative contraindication for oxytocin administration. It requires careful monitoring and assessment by the healthcare provider, but it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Premature labour: Oxytocin can sometimes be used to manage labor in preterm situations under strict medical supervision. It is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is not a contraindication for the use of oxytocin. Proper management of hypothyroidism is necessary during pregnancy, but it does not specifically preclude the use of oxytocin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is contraindicated in malpresentation of the fetus, grand multipara, contracted pelvis, history of classical cesarean, history of 2 or more LSCS, obstructed labor, fetal distress, and hypovolemia.

 

Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226th edition

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

questions.text: A skin rash gets exaggerated on sun exposure is repaired by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair

 

 

Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from the sun causes damage to DNA by inducing the formation of thymidine dimers, which are covalent linkages between adjacent thymine bases on a DNA strand. These dimers distort the DNA structure, interfering with replication and transcription.

 

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the primary mechanism used by cells to repair this type of damage. The NER pathway identifies the bulky lesions caused by thymidine dimers, excises the damaged section of DNA, and fills in the gap with the correct nucleotides using a DNA polymerase.

 

A defect in this repair mechanism can lead to xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, leading to severe sunburns, rashes, and a high risk of skin cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair: This mechanism repairs small, non-bulky DNA lesions such as single-base alterations, including deamination and oxidative damage. It does not correct UV-induced thymidine dimers.

 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA break repair: This repair mechanism is involved in fixing double-strand breaks, which occur due to radiation, replication errors, or certain chemicals. It does not address thymidine dimers.

 

Option C. Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as incorrect base pairing (e.g., A-C instead of A-T). It is not involved in repairing damage from UV light exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleotide excision repair is the primary DNA repair mechanism that corrects damage caused by UV light, such as thymidine dimers.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Usually a sequela of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis.
  • Causative organism: staphylococcus aureus
  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Discharge: Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain: Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever etc., are present only during acute exacerbations.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
    • Sequestrum: It is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues. It acts as nidus of infection and is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis. A chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge may be seen.
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. It is usually obvious by the end of 2nd week.
    • If infection persists, pus and tiny sequestrated spicules of bone may continue to discharge from the perforations called cloacae.

 

 

  • Rim sign is seen on MRI.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Paprika sign is the appearance of the live bone after removal of sequestrum.
       

 

  • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
  • Various surgical options are:
    • Sequestrectomy
    • Saucerisation
    • Curettage
    • Excision of an infected bone
    • Amputation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Stress fracture of tibia. A tibial shaft stress fracture is an overuse injury where normal or abnormal bone is subjected to repetitive stress, resulting in microfractures. It is commonly seen in runners. There is linear microfracture in trabecular bone from repetitive loading. The patient have pain directly over the fracture which initially worsen after running. Diagnosis can often be made on radiographs alone but MRI studies should be obtained in patients with normal radiographs with a high degree of suspicion for stress fracture. Lateral x-ray shows dreaded black line anteriorly, endosteal thickening, periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. Treatment is activity restriction with protected weight-bearing in most cases. Surgical intramedullary nailing is recommended in the presence of an anterior tibia tension-sided stress fracture ("dreaded black line").

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. This condition leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neurons, which can be observed as a cherry red spot in the macula of the retina. However, unlike other sphingolipidoses, Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fabry's disease: Fabry's disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-Galactosidase and is an X-linked recessive disorder. This condition does not typically present with a cherry red spot and is associated with other symptoms such as angiokeratomas and renal complications.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme β-Glucosidase. It is typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly, and while cherry red spots can rarely be seen, it is not a common feature of the disease. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly distinguishes it from Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Option D. Von Gierke disease: Von Gierke disease (Glycogen storage disease type I) is not a lysosomal storage disorder or a sphingolipidosis. It is associated with glycogen metabolism and does not present with cherry red spots. This disease also features hepatomegaly, which is not consistent with the condition described in the question.

 

Additional Information

 

  • All sphingolipidoses are autosomal recessive except for Fabry's disease, which is X-linked recessive.
  • All sphingolipidoses are associated with mental retardation except for Gaucher's disease and Fabry's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have hepatosplenomegaly except for Tay-Sachs and Krabbe's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have a cherry red spot in the eye except for Fabry's and Gaucher's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses with angiokeratoma include GM1 gangliosidosis and Fabry's disease.
  • Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling rheumatoid arthritis or idiopathic juvenile arthritis include Farber's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling sickle cell crisis include Fabry's disease.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.

 

Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: A particular community population has been consuming Maize as a staple diet for years. The vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this population is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Niacin

 

Maize, commonly consumed as a staple food in many communities, is deficient in the amino acid tryptophan, which is crucial for the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3) in the body. Niacin can be synthesized endogenously from tryptophan at a conversion rate of 60 mg of tryptophan to 1 mg of niacin. However, when maize is a primary dietary component, the body lacks sufficient tryptophan, leading to niacin deficiency.

 

Moreover, maize is high in leucine, an amino acid that inhibits the conversion of tryptophan to niacin via the kynurenine pathway. This combination of low tryptophan and high leucine content makes niacin deficiency prevalent in populations consuming maize as a staple diet, resulting in pellagra.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the “4 Ds”: Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and Death if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency is typically associated with polished rice consumption, not maize. It leads to conditions like beriberi.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, though possible, is not specifically linked to maize consumption. It typically results from general dietary insufficiency of various foods, not specific to maize.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin: Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency is generally seen in populations with low intake of animal products and is not related to maize consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maize as a staple diet leads to niacin deficiency due to its low tryptophan and high leucine content, resulting in pellagra.

 

Note – Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India

choices.text: It is caused by staphylococcus only
It is a case of testicular torsion

questions.text: A 40-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the correct statement about this condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The testis remains unaffected

 

The patient's presentation, along with the examination findings, suggest Fournier's gangrene. This is a life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal and genital regions requiring prompt medical and surgical intervention.

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is characterized by rapid progression and extensive tissue necrosis. It is a polymicrobial infection often involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria from gastrointestinal or genitourinary sources. Immediate treatment includes surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

 

The infection in Fournier's gangrene usually affects superficial tissues and skin but spares the testes due to their separate blood supply from the testicular artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by staphylococcus only: Incorrect. While Staphylococcus species can be involved, Fournier's gangrene is typically polymicrobial, involving multiple bacteria such as E. coli, Klebsiella, and anaerobes, along with staphylococci.

 

Option C. It is a self-resolving condition: Incorrect. Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressing and severe condition that requires urgent surgical and medical treatment. Without intervention, it can lead to sepsis and be fatal.

 

Option D. It is a case of testicular torsion: Incorrect. Testicular torsion involves twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to acute severe scrotal pain and ischemia of the testis. This condition is different from Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier's gangrene is a severe necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital regions, often sparing deeper structures like the testes. Immediate surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics are critical for management.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive investigation for parathyroid tumor imaging?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc Sestamibi SPECT

 

Explanation:

 

For the imaging of parathyroid tumors, particularly in the context of hyperparathyroidism, several modalities can be employed. Each has its strengths and particular clinical situations where it might be the preferred choice.

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography technique also utilizes Technetium-99m sestamibi but combines it with CT imaging to provide three-dimensional imaging. This makes SPECT more sensitive than a plain sestamibi scan for locating parathyroid tumors, especially when they are ectopic or embedded deep within the neck or chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan: This is a nuclear medicine scan that uses a small amount of a radioactive compound , typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by active parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. While sensitive, it provides a two-dimensional view which can sometimes make precise localization of smaller or deeper tumors challenging.

 

Option C. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is useful for imaging the parathyroid glands due to its non-invasive nature and ability to detect lesions in real-time. It is particularly effective for glands located in typical positions near the thyroid. However, its effectiveness diminishes for ectopic glands or in obese patients where acoustic windows may be poor.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in complex cases, such as when other imaging modalities fail or in surgical planning. However, its sensitivity is generally lower than Sestamibi SPECT for detecting parathyroid adenomas, and it is less commonly used primarily due to higher costs and limited availability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly because it offers three-dimensional localization capabilities that can greatly assist surgeons in planning minimally invasive surgery.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bcl-2

 

The anti-apoptotic factor among the following is BcI-2.

 

Apoptosis is a process of programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms. It is a highly regulated process that involves a complex network of proteins and signaling pathways. Among the proteins involved in apoptosis are two families of proteins known as the Bcl-2 family and the caspase family.

 

The Bcl-2 family of proteins includes both pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members. The pro-apoptotic members include Bax, Bak, and others, while the anti-apoptotic members include Bcl-2, Bcl-XL, and others. The balance between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family is important in determining whether a cell will undergo apoptosis or not.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P-53: P-53 is a tumor suppressor protein known for its role in preventing cancer. It can induce apoptosis but is generally considered a promoter of cell cycle arrest and DNA repair in response to DNA damage, rather than being anti-apoptotic.

 

Option B. K-ras: K-ras is an oncogene that, when mutated, contributes to cancer progression by promoting cellular proliferation and survival, not directly inhibiting apoptosis.

 

Option D. BAK: BAK, like Bax, is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family. It promotes apoptosis by facilitating mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, which is a critical step in the activation of the apoptotic pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bcl-2's anti-apoptotic properties make it a key player in cellular survival and stress response. Its ability to inhibit key steps in the apoptotic process distinguishes it from other proteins like P-53, K-ras, and BAK, which have different roles in the regulation of cell death and proliferation.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

questions.text: First line of treatment for glaucoma in adults is:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PG analogues

 

These are typically the first choice for the long-term management of glaucoma due to their efficacy and favourable patient adherence factors.

 

Prostaglandin analogues are a class of medications used as the first-line treatment for glaucoma. They work by increasing the outflow of the aqueous humor from the eye, which lowers intraocular pressure. These drugs are preferred due to their effectiveness and once-daily dosing, which improves patient compliance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: is a muscarinic antagonist and is not used for the treatment of glaucoma. It dilates the pupil, which can potentially worsen glaucoma, especially angle-closure glaucoma, by blocking the drainage of the aqueous humor from the eye.

 

Option C. Acetazolamide: is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces the production of aqueous humor in the eye, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. It is not typically the first-line treatment due to the potential for systemic side effects and the presence of more effective topical treatments.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a cholinergic agonist that contracts the ciliary muscle and opens the trabecular meshwork, allowing for increased outflow of aqueous humor. It is not usually the first choice for the chronic treatment of glaucoma due to its frequent dosing and side effects but can be used in acute angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for adult glaucoma is Prostaglandin Analogues, which are effective in lowering intraocular pressure with a convenient dosing schedule.

questions.text: A girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield -shaped chest, swelling of the ankle, and increased carrying angle. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

The constellation of symptoms including short stature, webbed neck, thick calves, shield-shaped chest, swelling of the ankles, and increased carrying angle is suggestive of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is caused by complete or partial X-chromosome monosomy. In phenotypic females, it causes hypogonadism. In females, it is the most common sex chromosome abnormality.

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries, infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Down syndrome: (Trisomy 21) is characterized by intellectual disability, facial dysmorphism, and increased risk of certain medical conditions such as congenital heart defects and leukemia.

 

Option C. Patau syndrome: (Trisomy 13): characterised by severe intellectual disability, cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, microcephaly, congenital heart defects, and often leads to early infant mortality.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: (Trisomy 18) characterised by severe intellectual disability, micrognathia (small jaw), clenched fists with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart defects, and also typically results in early infant mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield-shaped chest, peripheral lymphedema, and increased carrying angle, among other physical manifestations. It is caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome in phenotypic females.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents in OPD with a history of fever and cough for 5 days. On auscultation, crepts were heard on right side. Chest X-ray is given below. Mark the correct finding in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right middle lobe consolidation

 

Patient presenting with a history of fever and cough for 5 days suggests diagnosis pneumonia. The chest X-ray showing opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation.

 

Right middle lobe pathology causes the obscuration of right cardiac border. In addition, the lateral view shows the opacity overlying the heart. In case of lower lobe opacities, the opacity overlays the spine.

 

 

The left image is a normal chest radiograph with the red line indicating the silhouette of the right heart border and right middle lobe.

 

The right image shows the same red line delineating where the silhouette should be, but is lost due to consolidation in the right middle lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right middle lobe consolidation is suggested by the obscuration of the right heart border and the specific location of opacity on the chest X-ray, aligned with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory symptoms. This finding is crucial for diagnosing the specific location of pneumonia, guiding appropriate treatment.

choices.text: Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
No exchange of O2 & CO2
CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood
Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal

questions.text: Va/Q = infinity means? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. No exchange of O2 & CO2

 

Explanation

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

  • This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow
  • When the ventilation (Va) is zero, yet there is still perfusion (Q) of the alveolus, the Va/Q is zero.
  • When there is adequate ventilation (Va) but zero perfusion (Q), the ratio Va/Q is infinity.
  • At a ratio of either zero or infinity, there is no exchange of gases through the respiratory membrane of the affected alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero: Incorrect as partial pressure of O2 will be high in the alveoli but without perfusion, no exchange occurs.

 

Option C. CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood: Incorrect because without perfusion, there's no blood flow to equilibrate CO2 levels.

 

Option D. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal: Incorrect because, although the partial pressures in the ventilated alveoli might appear normal or even high for O2, without perfusion, these gases are not effectively exchanged with the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ventilation-perfusion (Va/Q) ratio of infinity, indicative of ventilation without perfusion, results in no exchange of oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) due to the absence of blood flow to the ventilated alveoli. This scenario highlights the critical balance needed between air delivery to the lungs and blood flow through the pulmonary circulation for effective respiratory gas exchange.

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal).
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpox‐type lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: False. In herpes zoster, it is the dorsal (posterior) nerve roots and ganglia that are predominantly involved, not the anterior nerve roots. The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia and reactivates there, leading to symptoms in the corresponding dermatomal distribution.

 

Option C. The lesions are not infectious: False. The lesions of herpes zoster are highly infectious, particularly when the blisters are open and the fluid is accessible. The virus contained in these lesions can infect individuals who have not previously had chickenpox or the vaccine, leading to varicella (chickenpox).

 

Option D. Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: False. While the trigeminal dermatome can be significantly affected (especially concerning due to the risk of herpes zoster ophthalmicus if the ophthalmic branch is involved), it is not the most commonly affected dermatome. The thoracic dermatomes are more frequently involved in herpes zoster cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

 

The LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device. Second-generation devices are designed to be safer than first-generation devices, offering a higher pressure pharyngeal seal and a reduced risk of aspiration. These devices often have two tubes: one for ventilation (airway tube) and another for draining gastric secretions (gastric tube). The LMA Proseal, specifically, features these characteristics, making it a second-generation device.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA Fastrach: LMA Fastrach, also known as the intubating LMA, is not categorized as either a first or second-generation device. It is classified as a special LMA due to its unique design, which facilitates difficult intubations.

 

 

Option B. LMA Flexible: The LMA Flexible is a variant of the LMA Classic, which is a first-generation device. It has a flexible airway tube but lacks the features of second-generation devices, such as a high-pressure pharyngeal seal and an additional tube for gastric drainage.

 

 

Option D. Ambu LMA: The Ambu LMA does not have the dual-tube system that characterizes second-generation devices.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

questions.text: An investigation was conducted to evaluate the nutritional status of young children residing in both rural and urban regions. Among the participants, 30 children from rural areas and 20 children from urban areas were found to be malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Chi Square test

 

The Chi Square test can be used to determine whether there is a significant association or relationship between two categorical variables. In this case, the two variables are the nutritional status (malnourished or not malnourished) and the location (rural or urban), both of which are Qualitative characters.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paired T test:  is used when comparing the means of two related samples, such as before and after measurements for the same group.

 

Option C. Standard error of the mean:  is a measure of the variability of sample means.

 

Option D.  ANOVA:  is used to compare the means of three or more groups.

These tests are not appropriate for analyzing the relationship between two categorical variables as in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Chi Square test is the appropriate statistical test for evaluating the association between two categorical variables, such as nutritional status (malnourished vs. not malnourished) and location (rural vs. urban).

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Measles

 

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads primarily through the air via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Its high transmissibility requires that patients be isolated in airborne infection isolation rooms to prevent the spread of the virus to others, particularly the unvaccinated or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, rabies does not require airborne isolation as it is not spread through the air.

 

Option C. Nipah: While Nipah virus can be transmitted from person to person, it is primarily spread through direct contact with infected bats, pigs, or other Nipah-infected individuals' body fluids. Airborne transmission is not the primary mode.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis: Generally caused by viral infections and not considered highly contagious through the air. Transmission is typically through direct contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to treat hypertension and edema. It is not specifically known to delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. While it helps in managing blood pressure, it does not have the protective renal effects seen with other medications listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: These drugs, such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been shown to provide renal protection by reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by decreasing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to osmotic diuresis and reduced glomerular hyperfiltration.

 

Option B. Finerenone: This is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA) approved for the treatment of chronic kidney disease in type 2 diabetes. It helps to reduce albuminuria and slows the progression of renal disease.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs, such as losartan and valsartan, are well-known for their renal protective effects. They help reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy by blocking the effects of angiotensin II on the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

 

The most common fixative used in a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). This fixative helps preserve the cells collected on the slides for cytological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formalin: Formalin (10%) is commonly used as a fixative for histology specimens but is not used for Pap smears.

 

Option B. Air dried: Air drying is not a method used for preserving Pap smear specimens as it can lead to poor preservation of cellular details.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. Tissues must be immediately transferred to formol saline if using normal saline temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

 

The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique of Halstead involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak. This is one of the preferred techniques in small bowel anastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The surgeon must use chromic catgut:  Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. Chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress, including intestinal anastomosis.

 

Option B. The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option D. The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:


The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histamine 

 

Histamine is involved in the mediation of inflammatory vascular events rather than fever.

 

Fever is defined by an increase in body temperature of 1° to 4°C. It is a prominent manifestation of the acute-phase response, particularly when associated with infection.

 

Pyrogens are substances that cause fever. They can be either exogenous or endogenous.

 

  • Endogenous progens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
  • Exogenous pyrogens are bacterial lipopolysaccharides that stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous progens (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Cytokines increase the activity of cyclooxygenases, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the hypothalamic vascular and perivascular cells. They stimulate the production of neurotransmitters in the hypothalamus, which raises the temperature setpoint. This is especially true of PGE2.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. IL-1, B. Prostaglandins and C. TNF: These are all endogenous pyrogens that directly contribute to the fever response by influencing the temperature regulation in the hypothalamus and stimulating the production of prostaglandins that raise the body’s temperature setpoint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
